statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Baylor 67, Colorado 59
article.story: WACO, Texas (AP) -- Led by Aaron Bruce's 14 points, Baylor surpassed last season's record of eight wins with a 67-59 victory over Colorado on Wednesday night. Baylor (9-5, 1-2 Big 12) had help from Tommy Swanson, who scored 13 points and grabbed 10 rebounds. "I was proud of the way we played in almost every phase," Baylor coach Scott Drew said. The Bears opened the second half with an 11-5 run and took a 45-34 lead over Colorado with just under 15 minutes remaining. Colorado (8-7, 0-4) pulled to within seven points twice, but the Bears sank 5-of-8 free throws in the final two minutes to clinch their first Big 12 win this season. "Once we were up, we had to take pride in that lead," Bruce said. "We were just looking to keep our noses in front while they made a good surge. It's a credit to our guys we were able to weather the storm." Baylor outscored Colorado 18-1 to open the game, holding the Buffaloes scoreless for almost nine minutes. "It was a great effort for Baylor," Colorado coach Ricardo Patton said. "They came out and made some shots early, and we dug ourselves a little bit of a hole." Colorado's Richard Roby led all scorers with 15 points, and Glean Eddy added 12 for the Buffaloes. Colorado reduced Baylor's lead to 34-29 as Roby scored 13 first half points. It was Baylor's first conference win since Feb. 25.
